Summary I am a seismologist with a strong interest in the development of earthquake early warning systems. I am currently working on improving earthquake detections for the ElarmS earthquake early warning system. As a graduate student at Stanford University, I worked with the Quake-Catcher Network (QCN) team to develop a world-wide low-cost seismic network using inexpensive MEMS accelerometers to record earthquakes. Experience Postdoctoral Research Scholar Berkeley Seismological Laboratory September 2014  – Present (1 year) For my postdoctoral research at the Berkeley Seismological Laboratory, I am exploring ways to improve the ElarmS earthquake early warning algorithm and methodology. I am particularly interested in using the frequency content soon after a trigger to determine whether or not the trigger was due to a local earthquake. Graduate Student Stanford University July 2008  –  August 2014  (6 years 2 months) Stanford, CA While at Stanford University, I expanded the network by leading teams to install hundreds of sensors in Chile, New Zealand, Mexico, and the San Francisco Bay Area. I then used the data to explore the rapid earthquake detection capabilities of the network. I also explored the use of MEMS sensors and the QCN network in determining the response of a building. The resolution of the sensors at the time was too low to calculate a good response, but the technology proved promising. QCN is also an excellent tool for teaching people of all ages about earthquakes and the physics of motion. Staff Research Associate Berkeley Seismological Lab June 2007  –  July 2008  (1 year 2 months) Berkeley, CA Investigated the rupture process of a sequence of repeating Mw2.1 earthquakes on the San Andreas Fault in Parkfield, CA. The developed system fused various data mining and information retrieval techniques such as near-duplicate detection, HTML content extraction, topic modeling on short texts, named entity recognition to deliver reliability-ranked, real-time and maritime-focused news articles. Developed novel and highly efficient and effective algorithms to extract information from XML databases using keyword search, especially when XML database contains irregular and evolutionary data. Summary I am a mechanical engineering graduate student at Stanford University with a concentration in energy systems and a minor concentration in reactive gas dynamics and combustion. I graduated from Loyola Marymount University with a bachelors degree in mechanical engineering with a minor in applied mathematics. As an engineer my interests include advanced combustion technologies and energy systems, renewable energy, nanotechnology, and space exploration. I look forward to pursuing these career aspirations in the top companies and firms in the industry. 
 
I have worked as a research assistant for two consecutive summers at top research universities in both material science and in mechanical engineering. I have also worked in a project management and engineering role for two construction management contracting firms on a $100M project in Southern California and on a $90M project in Miami, Florida. Through these experiences I have learned valuable lessons in both team work and also in leading independent projects without constant supervision. Experience Mechanical Engineering Graduate Student Stanford University April 2014  – Present (1 year 5 months) Stanford, CA Performing reactive gas dynamics research in the High Pressure Flow Reactor (HPFR) Facility under the guidance of Dr. C. T. Bowman. Most of the HPFR work focuses on studies of the combustion characteristics of jet and rocket fuels. Mechanical Engineering Intern Turner Construction Company June 2014  –  August 2014  (3 months) Miami/Fort Lauderdale Area I assisted on Turner's Brickell City Centre project in Miami, Florida. I collaborated with both the field team and the engineering team participating in the final stages of the project and the close-out phase, respectively. My duties in the field included taking equipment and man-power counts with the software e-Builder, checking in with city inspectors, and handling various safety procedures. My responsibilities with the engineering team consist of assisting on change orders, SISs, and contract reconciliations. Undergraduate Teaching Assistant Loyola Marymount University January 2012  –  May 2014  (2 years 5 months) Greater Los Angeles Area I aided professors in the mathematics, physics, and engineering department and handled various tasks. Driver August 2013  –  January 2014  (6 months) Greater Los Angeles Area I assisted in the planning, development, and implementation of the Loyola Marymount University Life Science Building, a $100+ M project. In my position I worked with senior project engineers, project managers, and superintendents on processing RFIs, product submittals, and construction drawings as well as ensuring proper workplace safety. Summary I'm currently a graduate student at Stanford University pursuing an M.S. and Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering, with a focus in fluid dynamics, studying under the combined support of a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship and a Stanford University Office of Technology Licensing Graduate Fellowship. I earned a B.S. in Engineering Mechanics from the University of Illinois with a minor in Computer Science and certificate in Technology Commercialization. I have a strong interest in entrepreneurship, and hope to use graduate study not only to explore research careers, but also opportunities with start-up and early stage companies working at the leading edge of technology. The summer of 2013 I worked as a volunteer intern with Bump Nonprofit Design Studio, a Champaign-Urbana based start-up currently focused on development of the OpenSocket, which is a universal fit prosthetic arm accessible to amputees in developing countries due to its extremely low cost. 
 
As an undergraduate student, I served as president of Illini Pride Student Athletic Board, a 3,600 member organization that includes the Block I, Orange Krush, and other student support groups for Illinois' athletic programs. With a long-time friend, I co-founded and ran HigherMed, Inc., a company whose goal was to design an easier-to-use pill-dispensing prescription bottle cap. Our start-up placed 2nd in the 2012 Cozad New Venture Competition at UIUC. I also enjoy music, particularly classical solo and choral works, and have performed as a baritone soloist or chorus member with a number of Champaign-Urbana groups including the Baroque Artists of Champaign-Urbana and the Champaign Symphony Orchestra. In addition, I've had the opportunity to perform the Star-Spangled Banner at Chicago Bulls, Chicago White Sox, and numerous Illinois athletic events. With a long-time friend, I co-founded and ran HigherMed, Inc., a company whose goal was to design an easier-to-use pill-dispensing prescription bottle cap. Our start-up placed 2nd in the 2012 Cozad New Venture Competition at UIUC. I also enjoy music, particularly classical solo and choral works, and have performed as a baritone soloist or chorus member with a number of Champaign-Urbana groups including the Baroque Artists of Champaign-Urbana and the Champaign Symphony Orchestra. In addition, I've had the opportunity to perform the Star-Spangled Banner at Chicago Bulls, Chicago White Sox, and numerous Illinois athletic events. I'm currently a graduate student at Stanford University pursuing an M.S. and Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering, with a focus in fluid dynamics, studying under the combined support of a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship and a Stanford University Office of Technology Licensing Graduate Fellowship. I earned a B.S. in Engineering Mechanics from the University of Illinois with a minor in Computer Science and certificate in Technology Commercialization. I have a strong interest in entrepreneurship, and hope to use graduate study not only to explore research careers, but also opportunities with start-up and early stage companies working at the leading edge of technology. Experience Graduate Student Stanford University September 2013  – Present (2 years) Stanford, CA Ph.D. research project to develop an MRI-based technique for measurement of particle concentration in turbulent flows. Co-Owner/Operator HigherMed, Inc. November 2011  –  December 2013  (2 years 2 months) Urbana-Champaign, Illinois Area HigherMed, Inc. exists with the goal of designing and marketing a low-cost, easy to use pill-dispensing prescription bottle cap. Our target market consists of individuals with arthritis or decreased dexterity, many of whom already request "easy-open" pill containers. The HigherMed pill-dispensing cap makes it easy to obtain a single pill at a time. Unlike electronic dispensers, our cap is low-cost and simple to use, installing directly to a standard pharmaceutical vial. 
 
As a co-founder, duties have (so far) included: 
* Currently working to gain feedback through consumer focus groups in order to reach a minimum viable product 
* Design and rapid prototyping of numerous iterations of our prototype 
* Incorporation of company 
* Placed 2nd ($5000 prize) in 2012 Cozad New Venture Competition, which included: 
*** 1-minute elevator pitch round 
*** Development of detailed 5-page business plan 
*** Final round consisted of 10 minute presentation for panel of experienced entrepreneurs Volunteer Intern Bump Nonprofit Design Studio May 2013  –  September 2013  (5 months) EnterpriseWorks, Champaign, IL I began my involvement with Bump as a senior design student at the University of Illinois. Working in a team of 5 students, we investigated the feasibility of moving from in-house molding of polymer parts to various commercial processes such as injection molding, thermoforming, and so on. The team also investigated the strength properties of the product both before and after several design revisions that would be integral to this manufacturing change. 
 
After the conclusion of the senior design project, I've continued to work with Bump over the summer as a volunteer intern. Projects include updating flat CAD template models for use in a water jet and re-design of in-house wooden molds. Most recently, I've been responsible for the creation of 3D CAD models of the polymer parts as well as the associated CAD mold designs to be used for thermoforming. President Illini Pride Student Athletic Board March 2012  –  April 2013  (1 year 2 months) Urbana-Champaign, Illinois Area Illini Pride is a 3,600 member organization whose mission is the promotion and student support of University of Illinois Athletics programs. As president for the 2012-13 school year I oversaw all of the organization's operations, including our 27-member executive board as well as a $100k+ budget. One of my primary goals has been to build the technological infrastructure of our growing organization. In 2012, Illini Pride set up an online registration system for the first time, and saw a 25% growth in membership over the previous year. We're currently in the process of implementing a membership management system to replace outdated Excel spreadsheets and paper lists.
